content.text: A petition for correction is a formal request submitted to the Local Civil Registry Office for the amendment, registration, or correction of civil documents. It addresses discrepancies in personal records such as birth, marriage, or death certificates in compliance with the Civil Registry Laws of the Philippines.

items: Correction of clerical or typographical errors
Change of first name or nickname
Certified true copy of the civil registry document
Supporting documents (e.g., school records, baptismal certificate)

content.text: Processing times vary with the type of petition, typically ranging from 2 to 3 months due to verification and evaluation procedures.

items: Consult the Civil Registrar for the specific petition type.
Complete and gather all required documents.
Submit the petition at the Local Civil Registry Office.
Undergo review and evaluation of the submitted documents.
Fulfill any publication requirements if needed.
Receive approval and issuance of the corrected document.
All supporting documents must be authentic and consistent.
Some petitions may require court approval for significant corrections.
Fees and processing times can vary depending on local policies.

content.text: For further inquiries, clients may visit the Local Civil Registry Office or contact the municipal office.

A court decree is an official judicial order that impacts civil records and may require subsequent updates to birth, marriage, or death certificates. It is issued after a legal proceeding and is integral to enforcing decisions that affect personal status or civil documentation.
Court decrees provide a legally binding resolution on matters concerning personal records, including amendments and judicial determinations on civil status.

items: Certified copy of the court decree
Application form as required by the LCRO

content.text: The processing period generally depends on the complexity of the decree and may range from several weeks to a few months.

Legitimation is the legal process through which a child born out of wedlock is recognized as legitimate under the law. This process involves formal proceedings and documentation in accordance with Philippine civil law.

items: Submission of supporting evidence (e.g., affidavits, court orders)
Compliance with legal requirements set forth by civil law
Certified birth certificate of the child
Court order or affidavit supporting legitimation
Valid IDs of the petitioner and relevant parties

content.text: Form 1A Birth is used to register and update birth records. It captures essential information such as the full name, date and place of birth, and parentage details, ensuring legal recognition and consistency of birth data.

items: Certified copy of the hospital birth record
Valid government-issued IDs of the parents
Affidavit of discrepancy (if corrections are needed)

content.text: The processing time typically ranges from 1 to 2 months, depending on the volume of applications and required verifications.

Form 2A Death is used for the registration and update of death records. It documents the essential details of the deceased, including the cause and date of death, ensuring accuracy in the official civil registry.

items: Certified copy of the hospital or medico-legal report
Supporting documents (e.g., death certificate from a medical facility)

content.text: Processing is generally completed within 1 to 2 months after submission, subject to verification of supporting documents.

Form 3A Marriage registers and updates marriage records, including information on the contracting parties, marriage date, and location. The form ensures that marital status is accurately documented for legal and administrative purposes.

items: Certified copy of the marriage contract or certificate
Supporting documents (e.g., community or church records)

content.text: The processing time for marriage records is usually between 1 to 2 months, depending on document verification.
